items.creator: Chris Woolston
items.title: Bleak financial outlook for PhD students in Australia
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02069-y

Unable to afford medicines, utilities and housing, some students expect to suspend their doctoral programmes or drop out.
items.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

items.creator: Alexandra Witze
items.title: The many roads to the red planet — a memoir
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02071-4

As three nations prepare to send spacecraft to Mars, a planetary scientist offers her personal tour of those who led the way. By Alexandra Witze
items.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

items.creator: Florencia A. Yannelli
items.title: The lockdown walk that inspired an experiment
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02074-1

Why do garden plants suddenly become invasive? One scientist couple turned their balcony into a lab to find out.
items.dc:creator: Florencia A. Yannelli

items.creator: Nikki Forrester
items.title: How the coronavirus pandemic is changing virtual science communication
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02075-0

Researchers flocked to join Skype a Scientist after COVID-19 closed their labs. The squid biologist who founded it explains how the science-communication platform has adapted.
items.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

items.title: Coronavirus research updates: University infections could soar even if students were tested weekly
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-00502-w

Nature wades through the literature on the new coronavirus — and summarizes key papers as they appear.

items.title: Your new lab partner: A mobile robot chemist
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02030-z

This autonomous mobile robot is designed to work alongside humans.

items.creator: Flora Graham
items.title: Daily briefing: Genetic evidence of Native American ancestry among Polynesian people
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02078-x

People from Polynesia and South America mingled around 800 years ago — though it’s not clear who visited whom. Plus: mounting evidence suggests coronavirus is airborne, and precise gene edits made to mitochondrial DNA for the first time.
items.dc:creator: Flora Graham

items.title: This material is almost as hard as diamond — but as light as graphite
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02061-6

A theoretical form of carbon called pentadiamond becomes thicker when stretched.

items.creator: Paul Wallin
items.title: Native South Americans were early inhabitants of Polynesia
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01983-5

DNA analysis of Polynesians and Native South Americans has revealed an ancient genetic signature that resolves a long-running debate over Polynesian origins and early contacts between the two populations.
items.dc:creator: Paul Wallin

items.creator: Benjamin Burger
items.title: A mobile robotic chemist
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2442-2

A mobile robot autonomously operates analytical instruments in a wet chemistry laboratory, performing a photocatalyst optimization task much faster than a human would be able to.
items.dc:creator: Benjamin Burger

items.creator: Daniel Jimenez-Blasco
items.title: Glucose metabolism links astroglial mitochondria to cannabinoid effects
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2470-y

In mice, persistent activation of mitochondrial cannabinoid receptors in astroglia impairs cellular glucose metabolism and lactate production, leading to an increase in redox stress in neurons and altered behavioural responses.
items.dc:creator: Daniel Jimenez-Blasco

items.creator: David J. Beerling
items.title: Potential for large-scale CO<sub>2</sub> removal via enhanced rock weathering with croplands
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2448-9

A detailed assessment of the techno-economic potential of enhanced rock weathering on croplands identifies national CO2 removal potentials, costs and engineering challenges if it were to be scaled up to help meet ambitious global CO2 removal targets.
items.dc:creator: David J. Beerling

items.creator: Marco Todesco
items.title: Massive haplotypes underlie ecotypic differentiation in sunflowers
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2467-6

Resequencing analyses of three species of wild sunflower identify large non-recombining haplotype blocks that correlate with ecologically relevant traits, soil and climate characteristics, and that differentiate species ecotypes.
items.dc:creator: Marco Todesco

items.title: How to reach another planet when a pandemic is hobbling yours
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02000-5

As the United States, China and the United Arab Emirates head to Mars, they must all commit to sharing what they find.

items.creator: Paul A. Muller
items.title: Microbiota modulate sympathetic neurons via a gut–brain circuit
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2474-7

A combination of gnotobiotic mouse models, transcriptomics, circuit tracing and chemogenetic manipulations identifies neuronal circuits that integrate microbial signals in the gut with regulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
items.dc:creator: Paul A. Muller

items.creator: Magomet Aushev
items.title: Mitochondrial genome editing gets precise
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01974-6

A bacterial toxin has been found that allows DNA in a cellular organelle called the mitochondrion to be precisely altered. This development could help to combat diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA.
items.dc:creator: Magomet Aushev

items.creator: Flora Graham
items.title: Daily briefing: Kill, confuse, eat — how to stop a plague of locusts
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02067-0

Inventive ways to tackle a second wave of locusts that threatens to devour East Africa's crops. Plus: Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has COVID-19, and San Quentin prison's coronavirus outbreak.
items.dc:creator: Flora Graham

items.creator: Ivan Gallotta
items.title: Extracellular proteostasis prevents aggregation during pathogenic attack
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2461-z

A systematic analysis of the proteostasis network of secreted proteins in Caenorhabditis elegans identifies numerous regulators of protein homeostasis outside the cell, and highlights the contribution of extracellular proteostasis to host defence.
items.dc:creator: Ivan Gallotta

items.creator: Ewen Callaway
items.title: Ancient voyage carried Native Americans’ DNA to remote Pacific islands
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02055-4

Finding that some Polynesians have genetic ancestry from South America supports long-held theory that ancient populations met and produced offspring.
items.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

items.creator: Xiaomeng Liu
items.title: Tunable spin-polarized correlated states in twisted double bilayer graphene
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2458-7

Twisted double bilayer graphene devices show tunable spin-polarized correlated states that are sensitive to electric and magnetic fields, providing further insights into correlated states in two-dimensional moiré materials.
items.dc:creator: Xiaomeng Liu

items.creator: Jan Gerrit Horstmann
items.title: Coherent control of a surface structural phase transition
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2440-4

A structural phase transition from metal to insulator on a solid surface is controlled by an ultrafast sequence of optical pulses.
items.dc:creator: Jan Gerrit Horstmann

items.creator: Beverly Y. Mok
items.title: A bacterial cytidine deaminase toxin enables CRISPR-free mitochondrial base editing
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2477-4

An interbacterial toxin that catalyses the deamination of cytidines within double-stranded DNA forms part of a CRISPR-free, RNA-free base editing system that enables manipulation of human mitochondrial DNA.
items.dc:creator: Beverly Y. Mok

items.creator: Olivier Pourret
items.title: Why scientists with children who have disabilities need a different career trajectory
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02043-8

As lockdowns ease, Olivier Pourret hopes that academia will take on board lessons about how to redefine career success.
items.dc:creator: Olivier Pourret

items.creator: Andrew Silver
items.title: Scientists in China say US government crackdown is harming collaborations
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02015-y

Investigations into foreign interference on US campuses have rattled researchers in both countries.
items.dc:creator: Andrew Silver

items.creator: Johannes Lehmann
items.title: Removal of atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> by rock weathering holds promise for mitigating climate change
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01965-7

Large-scale removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere might be achieved through enhanced rock weathering. It now seems that this approach is as promising as other strategies, in terms of cost and CO2-removal potential.
items.dc:creator: Johannes Lehmann

items.creator: Dyani Lewis
items.title: Mounting evidence suggests coronavirus is airborne — but health advice has not caught up
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02058-1

Governments are starting to change policies amid concerns that tiny droplets can carry SARS-CoV-2. And after months of denying the importance of this, the World Health Organization is reconsidering its stance.
items.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

items.creator: Claire Gizowski
items.title: Sodium regulates clock time and output via an excitatory GABAergic pathway
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2471-x

The authors demonstrate that clock time can be regulated by non-photic physiologically relevant cues and that such cues can drive unscheduled homeostatic responses via clock-output networks.
items.dc:creator: Claire Gizowski

items.title: Pulling carbon from the sky is necessary but not sufficient
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02001-4

Carbon dioxide removal is becoming a serious proposition. But it is not a substitute for aggressive action to cut emissions.

items.creator: Richard Cloutier
items.title: Author Correction: Elpistostege and the origin of the vertebrate hand
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2450-2

Author Correction: Elpistostege and the origin of the vertebrate hand
items.dc:creator: Richard Cloutier

items.creator: Alexander G. Ioannidis
items.title: Native American gene flow into Polynesia predating Easter Island settlement
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2487-2

Genomic analyses of DNA from modern individuals show that, about 800 years ago, pre-European contact occurred between Polynesian individuals and Native American individuals from near present-day Colombia, while remote Pacific islands were still being settled.
items.dc:creator: Alexander G. Ioannidis

items.creator: Clare Wenham
items.title: Women are most affected by pandemics — lessons from past outbreaks
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02006-z

The social and economic impacts of COVID-19 fall harder on women than on men. Governments need to gather data and target policy to keep all citizens equally safe, sheltered and secure.
items.dc:creator: Clare Wenham

items.creator: Inmaculada Martínez-Reyes
items.title: Mitochondrial ubiquinol oxidation is necessary for tumour growth
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2475-6

Oxidation of ubiquinol by the mitochondrial electron transfer chain drives tumour growth by maintaining the function of the oxidative Krebs cycle and de novo pyrimidine synthesis.
items.dc:creator: Inmaculada Martínez-Reyes

items.creator: Pierre J. Magistretti
items.title: How lactate links cannabis to social behaviour
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01975-5

An active component of cannabis has been shown to disrupt the delicate metabolic balance between neurons and non-neuronal cells called astrocytes, altering social behaviour in mice.
items.dc:creator: Pierre J. Magistretti

items.creator: Thierry Lonhienne
items.title: Structures of fungal and plant acetohydroxyacid synthases
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2514-3

Structures of fungal and plant acetohydroxyacid synthases
items.dc:creator: Thierry Lonhienne

items.creator: Sara Mahmoud H. Ahmed
items.title: Fitness trade-offs incurred by ovary-to-gut steroid signalling in Drosophila
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2462-y

High levels of the sexually dimorphic hormone ecdysone, produced by active ovaries in Drosophila, promote the proliferation of stem cells in the female gut and maximize reproductive fitness, but also increase female susceptibility to age-dependent dysplasia and tumorigenesis.
items.dc:creator: Sara Mahmoud H. Ahmed

items.creator: Shamini Bundell
items.title: The six-year-old space agency with hopes for Mars
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02056-3

On this week’s podcast, an ambitious Mars mission from a young space agency, and how crumbling up rocks could help fight climate change.
items.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

items.creator: R. D. Ferdman
items.title: Asymmetric mass ratios for bright double neutron-star mergers
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2439-x

Pulsar timing measurements show a mass ratio of about 0.8 for the double neutron-star system PSR J1913+1102, and population synthesis models indicate that such asymmetric systems represent 2–30% of merging binaries.
items.dc:creator: R. D. Ferdman

items.creator: Elizabeth J. Williamson
items.title: OpenSAFELY: factors associated with COVID-19 death in 17 million patients
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2521-4

OpenSAFELY: factors associated with COVID-19 death in 17 million patients
items.dc:creator: Elizabeth J. Williamson

items.creator: Noel H. Wan
items.title: Large-scale integration of artificial atoms in hybrid photonic circuits
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2441-3

An approach for integrating a large number of solid-state qubits on a photonic integrated circuit is used to construct a 128-channel artificial atom chip containing diamond quantum emitters.
items.dc:creator: Noel H. Wan

items.creator: Marissa Lingen
items.title: The foolish man built his house upon the sand
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02016-x

The ties that bind us.
items.dc:creator: Marissa Lingen

items.creator: Milica Momcilovic
items.title: Reply to: In vivo quantification of mitochondrial membrane potential
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2367-9

Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2366-x

In vivo quantification of mitochondrial membrane potential
items.dc:creator: Nathaniel M. Alpert

items.creator: Elizabeth Gibney
items.title: How a small Arab nation built a Mars mission from scratch in six years
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01862-z

The United Arab Emirates’ Hope orbiter is the Arab world’s first interplanetary spacecraft — and has jump-started science in the country. Will the momentum last?
items.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

items.creator: Jianhua Zhao
items.title: Irritant-evoked activation and calcium modulation of the TRPA1 receptor
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2480-9

Electrophiles activate the transient receptor potential ion channel TRPA1 by a two-step cysteine modification mechanism, which stabilizes a cytoplasmic loop that controls gating and calcium permeability.
items.dc:creator: Jianhua Zhao

items.creator: Heidi Ledford
items.title: Scientists make precise gene edits to mitochondrial DNA for first time
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02054-5

Weird enzyme enables researchers to study — and potentially treat — deadly diseases.
items.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

items.creator: Maria I. Giraldo
items.title: Envelope protein ubiquitination drives entry and pathogenesis of Zika virus
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2457-8

The E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIM7 polyubiquitinates the envelope protein of Zika virus, adding Lys63-linked polyubiquitin chains that interact with the TIM1 receptor of host cells to enhance virus entry and replication.
items.dc:creator: Maria I. Giraldo

items.title: Astronomers unveil epic X-ray map of the Universe
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02005-0

The latest science news, in brief.

items.creator: Flora Graham
items.title: Daily briefing: US international students face deportation if all their classes go online
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02048-3

The United States will withdraw an exemption that allowed foreign students on some visas to take all their classes online because of COVID-19. Plus: a post-pandemic exit plan for leaving academia, and three daring missions count down to Mars.
items.dc:creator: Flora Graham

items.creator: Alexandra Witze
items.title: Countdown to Mars: three daring missions take aim at the red planet
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01861-0

The United States, China and the United Arab Emirates will soon launch missions to a notoriously dangerous destination for spacecraft.

items.title: Don’t ask if artificial intelligence is good or fair, ask how it shifts power
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02003-2

Those who could be exploited by AI should be shaping its projects.
items.dc:creator: Pratyusha Kalluri

items.title: Why ancient people pushed deep into Mexico’s pitch-black caverns
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02031-y

Early residents of the Yucatán Peninsula mined a precious pigment from a vast labyrinth of subterranean passages.

items.creator: César Marín
items.title: Fight prejudice at all levels: from airports to conferences
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02039-4

Fight prejudice at all levels: from airports to conferences

items.title: China’s massive effort to collect its people’s DNA concerns scientists
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01984-4

Genetic material is being collected from men across the country to help solve crimes, but researchers worry the data will be misused.

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02051-8

The funding agency has taken action in 16–20 cases in which foreign ties were not properly reported.
items.dc:creator: Andrew Silver

items.creator: Amy Maxmen
items.title: California's San Quentin prison declined free coronavirus tests and urgent advice — now it has a massive outbreak
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02042-9

The storied prison is dealing with the third-largest coronavirus outbreak in the United States. Researchers fear that other institutions are at risk.
items.dc:creator: Amy Maxmen

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02033-w

items.title: Seeking an ‘exit plan’ for leaving academia amid coronavirus worries
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02029-6

The pandemic is prompting some early-career researchers to rethink their hopes for a university post.
items.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

items.creator: Flora Graham
items.title: Daily briefing: Huge data set reveals COVID-19’s unequal toll in the United States
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02036-7

Black and Latino people have been three times as likely as white people to be infected with the coronavirus in the US. Plus: everything we don’t know about COVID-19, and the ever-present threat of chemical weapons.
items.dc:creator: Flora Graham

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01999-x

COVID-19 is exposing the fragility of the goals adopted by the United Nations — two-thirds are now unlikely to be met.
items.dc:creator: Robin Naidoo

items.creator: Petr Stepanov
items.title: Untying the insulating and superconducting orders in magic-angle graphene
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2459-6

Tuning the electronic interactions by changing the dielectric environment of twisted bilayer graphene reveals the disappearance of the insulating states and their replacement by superconducting phases, suggesting a competition between the two phases.
items.dc:creator: Petr Stepanov

items.creator: Amber Dance
items.title: Gearing up for a ‘monumental’ mission to Mars
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01933-1

Engineer and roboticist Zach Ousnamer is helping to prepare NASA’s Perseverance rover for its launch to the red planet.
items.dc:creator: Amber Dance

items.title: Human thirst set to draw down mountains’ water banks
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02028-7

One-quarter of the global lowland population could depend on water from higher elevations by mid-century.

items.creator: Emma Stoye
items.title: Daily briefing: Cosmologists are mapping invisible magnetic fields that pervade the Universe
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02022-z

Curved magnetic fields could have arisen in the first instants after the Big Bang. Plus: the best evidence yet for the existence of particle-like anyons, and how sewage surveillance could be used to track coronavirus outbreaks.
items.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

items.creator: Ewen Callaway
items.title: Six months of coronavirus: the mysteries scientists are still racing to solve
items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01989-z

From immunity to the role of genetics, Nature looks at five pressing questions about COVID-19 that researchers are tackling.
items.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

items.creator: Noah Baker

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02020-1

Biosecurity experts use military-style exercises to plan for biological threats. Have their warnings been heeded?
items.dc:creator: Noah Baker

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02009-w

What the reproduction number can and can’t tell us about managing COVID-19.

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01985-3

The gases that envelop the distant dwarf planet might finally be freezing out and falling to the surface.

items.content:encoded:

The ‘quasiparticles’ defy the categories of ordinary particles and herald a potential way to build quantum computers.

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-02010-3

Divers found stone tools belonging to people that lived more than 7,000 years ago. Plus: an image library with offensive tags has been pulled offline, and a fire has destroyed important specimens at a museum in Brazil.
items.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

items.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 July 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-01987-1

A research institute that appointed Pier Paolo Pandolfi as its scientific director has reversed its decision after internal protests.

title: Nature - Issue - nature.com science feeds
description: Nature is the international weekly journal of science: a magazine style journal that publishes full-length research papers in all disciplines of science, as well as News and Views, reviews, news, features, commentaries, web focuses and more, covering all branches of science and how science impacts upon all aspects of society and life.
